data.title: Ramona (1910)
data.meta_description: Ramona, residing on her wealthy Spanish adoptive mother's rancho in California, falls in love with the Indian Alessandro. When Ramona is denied permission to marry Alessandro, the lovers elope, only to find a life of great hardship and unhappiness amidst the greed and injustice of the white landowners.
data.text:
Tras un intertítulo que reza "The Intuition", Ramona se levanta en el interior de su granja como impulsada por un resorte y se asoma al exterior. Sale y, bajo las vigas de su porche, dirige su mirada hacia un punto en el fuera de campo. Allí encontrará a su amado Alessandro. Por sus movimientos y por el contenido del intertítulo, lo que ha pasado parece claro: ha intuido la (inesperada) cercanía de Alessandro, que llevaba mucho tiempo lejos de la granja.

46 años después, John Ford abrió The Searchers con dos planos que nunca han dejado de maravillarme. Una mujer, Martha, sale al porche de su granja y posa su mirada en el horizonte, como si esperase encontrar justo lo…

Giving Griffith any sort of credit for his treatment of race feels risky, but here he does seem to imagine the human costs of western expansion and white imperialism, and he makes an effort to break taboos around interracial marriage.

These efforts at social critique seem half-hearted though. Ramona's discovery that she "has Indian blood" feels like a directorial stamp of approval on the relationship, a necessary addition for the sensibilities of the audience that in turn reduces the marriage to an affirmation rather than a rejection of prevailing "American" values. Likewise, Alessandro is a vehicle for manipulating the audience's emotions rather than a human figure, a stereotype to be exploited for cheap tears, much like Uncle Tom. At the…

Never mind the nuanced take on NAs, that’s something written into the history books by the Daughters of the Confederacy. You can’t treat one peoples like animal demons without saving yourself room for a little pity over that other race you finished obliterating a few years before. It gives white people some color and maybe a little less ‘total asshole’ to at least feel bad that they never stood by their treaties or accept, say, the Cherokees as their sovereign neighbors, instead of pushing them into Oklahoma. Plus, a lot of us white people today have Cherokee or Creek blood in us anyway. There was plenty of intermarriage happening before, during and after the tribal lines were scrubbed off the…

Early version of Hellen Hunt Jackson's novel, which tells the story of Ramona (Mary Pickford), a Spanish woman who goes to stay with relatives in California where she is expected to marry a Spanish man. Ramona eventually falls in love with an Indian (Henry B. Walthall), which sets off racism in the white community.

Here's another message picture from Griffith who uses the full title to include "The Story of the White Man's Injustice to the Indian". Griffith often stood up and made these type of pictures to protect the rich or minorities and this film fits into that same mode.
